tokenized_answer: A curriculum reform was to carry out throughout Wales.

The group discussed with Estyn about the obstacles and difficulties faced by secondary schools when bringing the reform into practice, such as teacher shortage and lack of funds, and how Estyn tackled them.
Then the council questioned Estyn over their inspection over local authorities' educational services including regional consortia and independent schools.
In addition, the group also talked about specific skill development of literacy and numeracy, concluding that literacy should be the top priority of the progress.
They also dug into concerns regarding students' economic background and the schools' ability to care for students' mental well-being.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: We also know that qualifications take a very prominent role in secondary schools’ mindsets, and, in some cases, perhaps excessively so.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: So, we need to ensure that those qualifications are reformed as a result of the reform of the curriculum, and, of course, Qualifications Wales is carrying out that work currently.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: I think it's probably true to say that secondary schools have a greater challenge than primary schools generally in terms of preparedness for the new curriculum.

evidence.speaker: Suzy Davies AM
evidence.content: The final question from me is: there's a general concern about the number of teachers that we have in the system at the moment, particularly at secondary level and in particular subjects as well.

evidence.speaker: Sian Gwenllian AM
evidence.content: Isn't that where the focus should be and any additional funding that's allocated?

evidence.speaker: Sian Gwenllian AM
evidence.content: Has Estyn done any themed work on that particular issue, or do you intend to do anything on that?

evidence.speaker: Lynne Neagle AM
evidence.content: There's been a consistent message from Estyn that that is the weakest part of the system in Wales.

evidence.speaker: Sian Gwenllian AM
evidence.content: It does cause one concern, because if the teaching and learning standards just stay the same in the secondary sector, and we know that 12 per cent of secondary schools are under Estyn review and 11 per cent of them are in special measures, we're talking about half of the schools almost, and no improvement in the teaching quality in general.

evidence.speaker: Janet Finch-Saunders AM
evidence.content: The Minister recently told the committee that a number of recent Estyn inspections of local authorities' education services have been disappointing.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: So, we've talking quite a bit about secondary schools this morning, and I think that, again, is a factor in those local authorities.

evidence.speaker: Janet Finch-Saunders AM
evidence.content: What is your latest assessment of how well the regional consortia are supporting and driving school improvement?

evidence.speaker: Jassa Scott
evidence.content: I think they've prioritised well the work that schools are doing around literacy and numeracy, but their support for schools to develop digital competence has been a bit weaker.

evidence.speaker: Jassa Scott
evidence.content: Even though we've had the framework as an early part of the curriculum developments there, we haven't seen quite the focus that we've seen on other areas.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: I think literacy has been, and still is, and still needs to be a top priority.

evidence.speaker: Dawn Bowden AM
evidence.content: Can I just move you on, then, to numeracy and whether you can tell us if you're satisfied with the progress in numeracy, because I think we were doing better on the PISA results in maths in Wales than we did previously?

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: And I think also, as I was suggesting about the reading, poverty really is a social phenomenon.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: So, there are a lot of caveats to be made around the fact that that poverty gap hasn't closed, but that's not to say that schools can't do something about it, and I've suggested in the annual report a sort of a two-pronged approach.

evidence.speaker: Lynne Neagle AM
evidence.content: Pupils' confidence in their school's ability to help them with their emotional and mental well-being is much less at secondary school and that's been a consistent theme as well from your reports.

specific_query_list.query: Summarize the difficulties carrying out the curriculum reform faced by secondary school.
tokenized_answer: First of all, although a number of primary schools have surplus funds, still a lot of secondary schools are in deficit and low on funds.
Also recent years have seen a shortage of teachers with appropriate initial teacher training.
There are concerns as well that schools in the bottom layer may find it difficult to adapt to the new curriculum and have little improvement on teaching quality.

evidence.speaker: Suzy Davies AM
evidence.content: Because we're in a situation where a number of primary schools have got surplus funds, sometimes that's because of end of year additional funds just being magicked up, but there is a serious worry that so many secondary schools are in deficit and that, overall, secondary schools are in deficit.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: Obviously, the most important resource for the education system is the teachers.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: So, it is a concern that recruitment is getting more and more difficult and that targets for initial teacher training are not being hit.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: I think it's probably true to say that secondary schools have a greater challenge than primary schools generally in terms of preparedness for the new curriculum.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: I think that's why we welcomed the phasing in of the new curriculum.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: With any sort of education reform, you've got that danger of people wanting to see change as soon as possible on the one hand, and on the other hand you need time to pilot things, to make sure that people have the right professional learning and make sure that there's opportunity for evaluation and thinking and so forth.

specific_query_list.query: What did Meilyr Rowlands think of the shortage of teachers?
tokenized_answer: Meilyr Rowlands thought it was a challenge to recruit new teachers and improve the initial training.In the long term, he believed that education should become more attractive for young people and more mature people to go into, while in the short term, looking at initial teacher training would be the top priority.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: So, it is a concern that recruitment is getting more and more difficult and that targets for initial teacher training are not being hit.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: So, long term, we've got to make sure that education is an attractive option for young people and more mature people to want to go into.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: There are short-term things we need to do, of course, as well.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: I think we need to have a much more varied set of routes into teaching, so I welcome some of the part-time Open University courses, for example.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: So, all those kinds of varied routes, I think, into teaching, are important as well.

specific_query_list.query: What did Meilyr Rowlands say about the additional challenge for secondary schools?
tokenized_answer: The children in secondary schools themselves are older and therefore have greater challenges.
As a result, it's also more difficult to engage with the parents of older children than younger children.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: So, there are many reasons why secondary schools find it more difficult, possibly, than primary schools.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: The children themselves are older and they have greater challenges.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: It’s more difficult to engage with the parents of older children than younger children, and that’s an important factor.

specific_query_list.query: What was Sian Gwenllian's concern about the schools in the bottom layer?
tokenized_answer: There were 12 percent of secondary schools under Estonian review and 11 percent of them were in special measures.
He worried that these schools lacked enough support and fundings to adapt to the new curriculum reform and face greater difficulties.

evidence.speaker: Sian Gwenllian AM
evidence.content: It does cause one concern, because if the teaching and learning standards just stay the same in the secondary sector, and we know that 12 per cent of secondary schools are under Estyn review and 11 per cent of them are in special measures, we're talking about half of the schools almost, and no improvement in the teaching quality in general.

evidence.speaker: Sian Gwenllian AM
evidence.content: So, there is a major cohort of children captured in that situation, and then there's a new curriculum that comes in.

evidence.speaker: Sian Gwenllian AM
evidence.content: Isn't that where the focus should be and any additional funding that's allocated?

specific_query_list.query: What did Jassa Scott talk about the work of regional consortia?
tokenized_answer: Jassa Scott believed they had prioritized the work that schools were doing around literacy and numeracy, yet the support for schools to develop digital competence were a bit weaker.
Also their support for secondary schools had less impact across the consortia than for primary schools.

evidence.speaker: Jassa Scott
evidence.content: I think they've prioritised well the work that schools are doing around literacy and numeracy, but their support for schools to develop digital competence has been a bit weaker.

evidence.speaker: Jassa Scott
evidence.content: I think, generally, their support for secondary schools has had less impact across the consortia than it has for primary schools, and I think sometimes that's because they're struggling to recruit appropriate specialists, to support with secondary, or perhaps they don't have the depth of strong practice that we talked about earlier within their region.

specific_query_list.query: What did Jassa Scott and Janet Finch-Saunders agree on the priority of the inspections?
tokenized_answer: They agreed that the first area they would look specifically at would be the work of consortia to support curriculum work.
Local government legislation were also under debate, which was an opportunity to adapt the inspection to look specifically at their work.

evidence.speaker: Jassa Scott
evidence.content: We will be, over the next year, looking specifically at the work of consortia to support curriculum reform work.

evidence.speaker: Jassa Scott
evidence.content: There's, obviously, local government legislation that has been debated recently, which has the potential to create corporate joint committees, and school improvement was one of the areas that is being considered there.

evidence.speaker: Jassa Scott
evidence.content: So, there may be an opportunity, if that's created, to think how we then adapt inspection to look specifically at that.

specific_query_list.query: What did Claire Morgan talk about the skill development in early year settings?
tokenized_answer: She held the view that children aged 3-5 were often introduced to things too early when they're not at that developmental stage.
As a result, in the long term children would lose confidence with a lot of negative impressions.

evidence.speaker: Claire Morgan
evidence.content: But in a minority of schools and settings, as you've picked up, children are often introduced to things too early.

evidence.speaker: Claire Morgan
evidence.content: So, they're introduced to phonics, they're introduced to learning to read, when they're not at that developmental stage.

evidence.speaker: Claire Morgan
evidence.content: These would be children from three to five.

evidence.speaker: Claire Morgan
evidence.content: And really, long term, it means the children lose confidence, because if they're introduced to these things too early they don't succeed, they tend to need additional support, and it can give them a negative impression, it can give them negative thoughts about their ability.

specific_query_list.query: What was the top priority in skills developing, according to Meilyr Rowlands?
tokenized_answer: He believed literacy still needed to be the top priority, because it was something that underpinned the rest of education.
Yet work was still needed to be done to continue prioritizing it.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: I think literacy has been, and still is, and still needs to be a top priority.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: I mean, literacy clearly is something that underpins the rest of education, so it really does need to be a top priority.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: I think it has been a high priority, but we need to continue prioritising it.

specific_query_list.query: What did the group talk about the progress in numeracy skills?
tokenized_answer: Meilyr Rowlands thought it was a fairly clear good news to see the improvements on the PISA results in maths, which could be attributed to the new GCSE mathematics numeracy.
Also they agreed it was a good news story to see much more mathematics knowledge to be applied in a problem-solving situation.
With regard to the effects of schools, Meilyr Rowlands held that the school had a larger effect on mathematics and science than reading.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: I think there is a fairly clear good news story here.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: PISA shows improvements and a lot of that can be attributed, I think, to the new GCSE mathematics numeracy.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: I think that that GCSE numeracy has built on the work that's been done lower down on the national numeracy framework, which has the same philosophy of applying that mathematics knowledge in a problem-solving situation.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: That has been a really good news story, really.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: The only other thing I would add is that there is some research that indicates or suggests that the effect of schools is greater on mathematics and science than on reading, and the reason for that is you don't do a lot mathematics or science in the home.

specific_query_list.query: What did Meilyr Rowlands say school could do about the poverty gap between pupils?
tokenized_answer: There was a two-pronged approach to solve the problem.
One is the new curriculum, which was all about improving the quality of teaching and learning in the classroom.
Poor pupils could gain more from it than their peers.
The other one was to have a community-focused approach to schools through helping the pupils and their families.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: So, there are a lot of caveats to be made around the fact that that poverty gap hasn't closed, but that's not to say that schools can't do something about it, and I've suggested in the annual report a sort of a two-pronged approach.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: One is the new curriculum.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: So, I think improving teaching and learning, and we discussed that earlier this morning about how the new curriculum is really all about improving the quality of teaching and learning in the classroom.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: I think there is evidence in the international research that teaching and learning, better teaching and learning, helps disadvantaged poor pupils disproportionately.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: So, they gain more from it that their peers.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: So, that's one approach, and then the other approach, which I've also mentioned earlier, is having a community-focused approach to schools.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: It means helping the pupils.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: It means helping their families.

specific_query_list.query: Why did pupils from better-off backgrounds do less well, according to Meilyr Rowlands?
tokenized_answer: Because they had to make sure that more able and talented children do well, who are mainly from poor backgrounds.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: So, it's not quite the same issue, but we've talked about the importance of making sure that more able and talented children do well.

evidence.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
evidence.content: They're not the same, clearly, because you have more able and talented children from poor backgrounds.

specific_query_list.query: Why did Jassa Scott believe it was more difficult for secondary schools to prioritize mental health and well-being?
tokenized_answer: First of all, secondary school pupils got to notice the differences between their everyday life at school and somehow felt not cared about.
It was also more of a challenge for a secondary school to provide an effective set of support from that whole-staff awareness of some of the challenges.
That is to say, it was more difficult for teachers in secondary schools to pick up signs that pupils may be struggling.

evidence.speaker: Jassa Scott
evidence.content: And I think what we find in secondary schools is perhaps secondary school pupils notice sometimes the differences between their everyday life that they experience in school and perhaps the messages that they're getting about well-being in terms of their lessons, in terms of assemblies and in terms of school policies and so on.

evidence.speaker: Jassa Scott
evidence.content: So, they are probably more discerning in noticing those differences and maybe there are some of those differences also there in primary school, but the pupils don't notice.

evidence.speaker: Jassa Scott
evidence.content: I think there's an element that it's more of a challenge for a secondary school to provide an effective set of support from that whole-staff awareness of some of the challenges.

evidence.speaker: Jassa Scott
evidence.content: So, maybe not every member of staff has the same level of understanding, but also those staff aren't spending the same amount of time with pupils.

evidence.speaker: Jassa Scott
evidence.content: So, in terms of getting to know pupils, picking up on signs that they may be struggling, or that there might be concerns—it's much more of a challenge.
